Class Room

java.lang.Object
  Room

public class Room
extends Object

Class Room - a room in an adventure game. This class is part of the "World of Zuul" application. "World of Zuul" is a very simple, text based adventure game. A "Room" represents one location in the scenery of the game. It is connected to other rooms via exits. For each existing exit, the room stores a reference to the neighboring room. Rooms can contain items and people which can be interacted with. Rooms can also be locked.

Version:
Author:
UP695745 and UP663678

Constructor Detail

Room

public Room(String description,
            String locked)
Create a room described "description". Initially, it has no exits. "description" is something like "a kitchen" or "an open court yard".

Parameters:
description - The room's description.
locked - A discription of the lock of the room. If they is no lock then null is used.
Method Detail

getExit

public Room getExit(String direction)
Return the room that is reached if we go from this room in direction "direction". If there is no room in that direction, return null.

Parameters:
direction - The exit's direction.
Returns:
The room in the given direction.

getItems

public ArrayList getItems()
Returns:
the list of items that are in the current room.

getItemsString

public ArrayList getItemsString()
Returns:
an arraylist containing the each item's name as a string.

getLock

public String getLock()
Returns:
the lock on the current room. Returns null if there is no lock.

getLongDescription

public String getLongDescription()
Return a description of the room in the form: You are in the kitchen. Exits: north west

Returns:
A long description of this room

getPeople

public ArrayList<Person> getPeople()
Returns:
the list of items that are in the current room.

public ArrayList getPeopleString()
Returns:
an arraylist containing the each person's name as a string.

getShortDescription

public String getShortDescription()
Returns:
The short description of the room (the one that was defined in the constructor).
